page.title: Molecules Properties Pane
page.introduction: The Molecules Properties Pane includes a graphical editor used to specify sites within Molecules using drop-menus that appear upon right mouse click in the Object Properties pane. An annotation box is also provided.
page.operations:
Rename a site or add a new site using the right mouse button to click on the molecule shape and select from the drop-down menu.
Add a state to a site, move or rename a site by right click on molecule site and selecting from the drop-down menu.
Anchor the molecule to a particular compartment or compartments within the physiology using the radio buttons in the Anchor Molecule region of the Properties Pane.
No restrictions places no restrictions on where the molecular type can exist; the molecule can participate in reactions with other molecules in any compartment. When a molecule with no restrictions binds to a molecule in a different compartment, the product molecule will reside within the compartment where the reaction occurs.
Structure Name selects compartments where the molecule is anchored. Anchoring to a compartment or compartments prevents the molecule from participating in reactions that do not occur within the selected compartment(s).
Anchoring prevents unwanted reactions from occurring, e.g. to prevent a membrane molecule from becoming a soluble molecule by binding to a cytosolic or extracellular molecule. Note that two molecules that do not share an anchored compartment cannot interact with each other. For example, a molecule anchored (restricted) to the membrane cannot bind to a molecule anchored (restricted) to the cytosol. The molecule in the cytosol must either have no anchoring restrictions or be anchored to both the membrane and the cytosol to participate in a reaction with a membrane-anchored molecule, and the reaction occurs in the membrane compartment. The product of the binding reaction in this example becomes a membrane-anchored molecule. Note that multiple anchors can be applied, but caution is advised as this can lead to unexpected results.
